metadata.title: Convert Kelvin to Rankine – Temperature Converter
metadata.description: Convert temperature from Kelvin (K) to Rankine (°R), useful for physics calculations with absolute temperature scales.

introduction: This converter transforms Kelvin to Rankine, both absolute temperature scales.
Both Kelvin and Rankine start at absolute zero but use different degree sizes.
This converter uses the relationship where 1 Kelvin equals 1.8 Rankines.
methodology: °R = K × 1.8. To convert Kelvin to Rankine, multiply by 1.8.
Both scales eliminate negative temperatures essential for thermodynamic calculations.
Understanding Kelvin-to-Rankine conversion bridges SI and imperial temperature scales.
This converter provides precise temperature conversion.

faqs.question: Why two absolute temperature scales?
faqs.answer: Kelvin: SI standard. Rankine: imperial equivalent. Same absolute zero, different degree sizes.

faqs.question: When would I use Rankine?
faqs.answer: Engineering in Fahrenheit-using countries. Mostly obsolete; Kelvin preferred.

faqs.question: What's the relationship?
faqs.answer: °R = K × 1.8. Same as Celsius to Fahrenheit conversion factor.

faqs.question: Can I convert directly K ↔ °F?
faqs.answer: Not directly; use intermediates. K→°R→°F or K→°C→°F.

faqs.question: Why absolute scales?
faqs.answer: Thermodynamics requires absolute temperature. Eliminates negative values in equations.

faqs.question: Is Rankine still used?
faqs.answer: Rare. Engineers may see it in older texts. Kelvin standard today.

faqs.question: What's triple point of water?
faqs.answer: 273.16 K = 491.688°R. Used historically to define Kelvin.

glossary.definition: Temperature scale with absolute zero at zero value.
